channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus News: Live Updates
item.description: Mitch McConnell, the Republican Senate leader, said states should consider declaring bankruptcy. The discovery of an early death rewrote the timeline of the U.S. outbreak.

item.title: Goggles, Masks, Ponchos: Air Travel in the Days of the Coronavirus
item.description: Some people who have had to board commercial flights in recent weeks have taken elaborate precautions to protect themselves from the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Lin and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: A traveler in protective gear wiped down his suitcase on Thursday at Los Angeles International Airport.

item.title: Trump Criticizes Gov. Brian Kemp for Decision to Reopen Georgia
item.description: “I think it’s too soon,” said the president, who joined several mayors in questioning Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, who had said some businesses could resume on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:description: Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia had long resisted statewide stay-at-home measures.

item.title: Texas Allows Abortions to Resume During Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: After weeks of wrangling in the courts, the state eased the restrictions on some surgical procedures, including abortion.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise
item.media:description: Texas authorities had said that elective procedures, including abortion, should be delayed to preserve personal protective equipment for medical workers.

item.title: Coronavirus, Tornadoes, N.F.L. Draft: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Vaccine Rates Drop Dangerously as Parents Avoid Doctor’s Visits
item.description: Afraid of Covid-19, parents are postponing well-child checkups, including shots, putting millions of children at risk of exposure to preventable deadly diseases.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carson Sheffield, 18 months old, was attended to by Dr. Mona Doss of Boston Medical Center, as Priscilla Stout, left, prepared a vaccine for him. The pediatric ambulatory department began sending mobile vaccination units into city neighborhoods last week.

item.title: ‘Staying Nimble’: How Small Businesses Can, and Do, Shift Gears
item.description: With the coronavirus restrictions, entrepreneurs are learning in real time just how they need to adapt to survive.
item.dc:creator: Amy Haimerl
item.media:credit: Whitten Sabbatini for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cristina McCarter owns a food tour company in Memphis. When the pandemic hit, she figured out a way to work with restaurants and take her business online.

item.title: New York and Boston Pigeons Don’t Mix
item.description: The East Coast is made up of two pigeon genetic megacities, and a patch of Connecticut seems to be what’s keeping them apart.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Sokol
item.media:credit: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pair of New York City pigeons.

item.title: Risky Strategy Has Produced Wins for Democrats in Fights Over Pandemic Aid
item.description: Now another struggle looms as Senator Mitch McConnell threatens a go-slow approach on the next round of economic stimulus, including aid to states.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: “Of the four major things we pushed for, we got three over Republican resistance,” said Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader.

item.title: You’re in the Army Now. Roll Up Your Sleeve.
item.description: Getting shots is part of the military. But an influenza vaccination Pfc. Monroe Scherer received in late 1945 made him sick for a week.
item.dc:creator: Jake Nevins

item.title: Protesting Without Gathering, Tenant Organizers Get Creative
item.description: Making the rent has gotten harder. So have conventional demonstrations. Housing activists are trying to raise their voices despite social distancing.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty and John Eligon
item.media:credit: Christopher Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: A van parked along Interstate 70 in Missouri as part of an event calling for tenant relief. “People are going to be homeless,” one of the passengers, Jenay Manley, said later.

item.title: More Than 4 Million Filed Unemployment Claims Last Week: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: The chief executive of Delta, Ed Bastian, told financial analysts on Wednesday his company was prepared to “make whatever changes to the business model that will be necessary.”

item.title: World Coronavirus Tracker: Live Coverage
item.description: The pandemic is shaking assumptions about American exceptionalism. Pakistani clerics override lockdown orders as Ramadan nears.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Berlin on Tuesday.

item.title: Executive Order Halting New Green Cards Includes Exceptions
item.description: The order will affect thousands of people seeking to immigrate to the United States, but it does not apply to immigrants already in the country, nor to those seeking temporary visas.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Mike Siegel/The Seattle Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Citizenship and Immigration Services office in Seattle last month.

item.title: McConnell Says States Should Consider Bankruptcy, Rebuffing Calls for Aid
item.description: The majority leader’s comments drew a strong rebuke from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: A death in early February suggests that the virus was already circulating in the U.S. while officials were still focused on quarantining travelers.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: Coronavirus Vaccine Doctor Says He Was Fired Over Doubts on Hydroxychloroquine
item.description: Rick Bright was abruptly dismissed this week as the director of the Department of Health and Human Services’ Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman
item.category: Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority
item.media:description: Rick Bright in 2018 during a House Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee hearing in Washington.

item.title: Tennessee Brothers Who Hoarded Hand Sanitizer Settle to Avoid Price-Gouging Fine
item.description: Matt and Noah Colvin reached a settlement this week with the state attorney general in the widely publicized price-gouging case.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Doug Strickland for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Colvin, an Amazon seller, in a rental truck stocked with boxes of hand sanitizer in Hixson, Tenn., last month.

item.title: Tornadoes Tear Through Oklahoma, Louisiana and Texas, Killing at Least 6
item.description: Homes were destroyed, two factories were damaged and thousands were left without power.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Neil Vigdor and Christine Hauser
item.media:description: One of a series of tornadoes that passed through Oklahoma, Louisiana and Texas on Wednesday. One person was killed in Marshall County, Okla.

item.title: Santa Clara County: First Known U.S. Coronavirus Death Occurred on Feb. 6
item.description: The startling discovery that the virus was responsible for a Feb. 6 death in California raises questions about where else it might have been spreading undetected.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller, Mike Baker, Shawn Hubler and Sheri Fink
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: The coronavirus was circulating in the Bay Area of California as early as January, even before the federal government began restricting travel from China on Feb. 2.

item.title: The Fear of Coronavirus and Flu Colliding in the Fall
item.description: Even as the president plays down that possibility, the C.D.C. chief and other experts warn of a dual challenge.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Dr. Robert Redfield, the C.D.C. director, spoke at a coronavirus briefing at the White House last week.

item.title: Harvard Won't Take Coronavirus Stimulus Money After Trump's Criticism
item.description: The university said it did not request $8.6 million in federal aid and would not apply for it.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Tristan Spinski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvard University’s campus last month. Harvard said in a statement that it faced “significant financial challenges” because of the pandemic and the resulting economic crisis.

item.title: Company Questions Deal by ‘Shark Tank’ Star to Sell N95 Masks to Florida
item.description: The company that makes the masks, 3M, said Daymond John’s firm The Shark Group was not an authorized distributor and appeared to have been selling them at an inflated price.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: A company that makes N95 masks said that Daymond John’s firm, The Shark Group, was not an authorized distributor and appeared to have been trying to sell the masks at a significantly inflated price.

item.title: The Cold Calculations America’s Leaders Will Have to Make Before Reopening
item.description: With no vaccine or cure, the president, governors, mayors and county executives will have to decide how many deaths would be acceptable to restore a shattered economy.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: A health worker transferring coronavirus patients to a hospital in the Bronx this month.

item.title: Tight-Knit Company Towns Reel as Coronavirus Rolls Through
item.description: Cases are leveling off in some coastal cities, but outbreaks are mounting in processing plants and factories in Midwestern towns.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Joseph Cress/Iowa City Press-Citizen, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Tyson Foods pork processing plant in Columbus Junction, Iowa, has had a cluster of coronavirus cases.

item.title: Q&A With a Trump Economic Adviser
item.description: We spoke to Stephen Moore, a member of President Trump’s economic task force, about the risks of reopening, what he’s advising the president and his predictions of a coming “economic civil war.”
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:description: Stephen Moore.

item.title: DeVos Excludes ‘Dreamers’ From Coronavirus College Relief
item.description: The education secretary told colleges that congressional relief for students dislocated by campus closures cannot go to undocumented immigrants, even those under federal protection.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos speaking at the White House last month. Ms. DeVos’s agency received more than $6 billion in emergency relief to give to students.

item.title: Two Cats Are First U.S. Pets to Test Positive for Coronavirus
item.description: The animals appear to have mild symptoms and likely caught the virus from their owners. And there’s no evidence pets can pass it to humans.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.media:description: Two pet cats in New York State tested positive for the virus but showed only mild symptoms and are expected to be fine.

item.title: Carole Brookins, a Rare Woman on 1970s Wall Street, Dies at 76
item.description: She was an expert in the global political economy, with a specialty in agriculture, and served as executive director of the World Bank. She fell victim to the novel coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:description: Carole Brookins, a former executive director of the World Bank, speaking at the Center for Financial Stability’s Bretton Woods conference in 2014.

item.title: The Social Media Challenges Helping Keep Boredom at Bay
item.description: From bouncing Ping-Pong balls off pots and pans for the perfect #TrickShot to turning pillows into D.I.Y. dresses, here’s how people are staving off cabin fever while in lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times
item.media:description: Viral challenges on TikTok, Facebook, Instagram and Twitter are helping social media users bat away the tedium of isolating at home.

item.title: House Democrats Retreat on Remote Voting as Republicans Clamor to Reopen
item.description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi scrapped a planned vote to change House rules to allow remote voting for the first time in Congress’s history, amid Republican opposition.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi, working with Representative Kevin McCarthy, the Republican leader, will have a bipartisan group of lawmakers consider remote voting proposals and plans to reopen the House.

item.title: U.S. Sailors’ New Reality: Confinement on Land and at Sea
item.description: Facing the risk of a coronavirus outbreak, the U.S. Navy is taking steps to sequester all sailors before they deploy.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The U.S.S. Ronald Reagan in Manila Bay in the Philippines last year.

item.title: A Seaside Irish Village Adopts Matt Damon
item.description: But don’t you dare ask what it’s like living under lockdown with Matt O’Damon.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:description: Matt Damon with Mary Caviston outside the Corner Note Café in Dalkey, Ireland.

item.title: Al Gore Endorses Joe Biden for President: ‘This Is Not Complicated’
item.description: The climate activist and former vice president announced his support on Earth Day and said, “If you want to start solving the climate crisis, this is not rocket science.”
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Courtney Pedroza/The Tennessean, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Al Gore in Nashville in November.

item.title: Orlando Moncada, a Building Foreman in Manhattan, Dies at 56
item.description: Mr. Moncada, who died of the coronavirus, left Peru 40 years ago in pursuit of the American dream. He grabbed it with both hands.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.media:description: Orlando Moncada came to the United States from Peru and started as a porter. He ended up a foreman.

item.title: Bennie G. Adkins, 86, Dies; Honored for Vietnam Heroics
item.description: He was awarded the Medal of Honor in 2014 for bravery in battle and aided veterans in his later years. He died of the new coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.category: United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)
item.media:description: President Barack Obama awarded the Medal of Honor to Bennie G. Adkins in a White House ceremony in 2014. He devoted his later years to helping Special Forces personnel readjust to civilian life.

item.title: ‘Pure Hell for Victims’ as Stimulus Programs Draw a Flood of Scammers
item.description: Trillions of dollars in stimulus funds have created a rush among criminals to take the money from those who need it the most.
item.dc:creator: Nathaniel Popper
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: September Dawn Bottoms for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It is a little relief, and then you find out it isn’t happening,” said Krystle Phelps, 33, who discovered that a scammer had recently claimed her family’s $3,400 stimulus check.

item.title: U.S. May Share Less Intelligence With Countries That Criminalize Homosexuality
item.description: The move is part of an effort by the acting director of national intelligence to prod countries that outlaw homosexuality to instead decriminalize it.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Office of the Director of National Intelligence
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Bernd von Jutrczenka/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The intelligence community should be pushing American values with the countries it does business with, Richard Grenell, the acting director of national intelligence, said in an interview this week.

item.title: Social Distancing for Coronavirus Has a History
item.description: The idea has been around for centuries. But it took a high school science fair, George W. Bush, history lessons and some determined researchers to overcome skepticism and make it federal policy.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton and Jennifer Steinhauer
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Bick for The New York Times
item.media:description: The concept of social distancing during a pandemic has been around since the Middle Ages. But it took a battle to make it an official policy response in the United States.

item.title: As Leaders Urge Face Masks, Their Behavior Muffles the Message
item.description: The medical guidelines are clear, but it’s not always an easy choice for image-conscious politicians.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Maggie Astor
item.media:description: Gov. Jared Polis of Colorado spoke with a maskless Mike Pence after the vice president’s arrival at Peterson Air Force Base in Colorado Springs on Saturday.

item.title: The Virus Won’t Revive F.D.R.’s Arts Jobs Program. Here’s Why.
item.description: The Federal Art Project, part of Roosevelt’s sweeping employment plan, gave work to thousands of artists, but politics and society were different then.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Federal Art Project/WPA, via Smithsonian Archive of America Art
item.media:description: Sculptors at work in New York under the auspices of the Works Progress Administration’s Federal Art Project. The program produced more than 18,800 pieces of sculpture.

item.title: PG&E Chief Executive to Retire in June
item.description: Bill Johnson joined the troubled utility last year and will leave when the company resolves its bankruptcy case.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis
item.media:description: Bill Johnson joined Pacific Gas & Electric, the troubled California utility, last May and plans to retire in June.
